natural problem: The coefficients of the polynomial $p(x)$ are all nonnegative integers.  If $p(1) = 4$ and $p(5) = 136,$ then find $p(6).$
natural solution: Let \[p(x) = a_n x^n + a_{n - 1} x^{n - 1} + \dots + a_1 x + a_0.\]Since $p(1) = 4,$ and all the coefficients of $p(x)$ are nonnegative integers, each coefficient $a_i$ of $p(x)$ is at most 4.

We also know \[p(5) = a_n 5^n + a_{n - 1} 5^{n - 1} + \dots + a_1 5 + a_0 = 136.\]Since $5^4 = 625 > 136,$ the degree $n$ of the polynomial can be at most 3, and we can write \[p(5) = 125a_3 + 25a_2 + 5a_1 + a_0 = 136.\]The only possible values of $a_3$ are 0 and 1.

Since \[25a_2 + 5a_1 + a_0 \le 25 \cdot 4 + 5 \cdot 4 + 4 = 124 < 136,\]$a_3$ cannot be 0, so $a_3 = 1.$  Then \[25a_2 + 5a_1 + a_0 = 136 - 125 = 11.\]This forces $a_2 = 0,$ so \[5a_1 + a_0 = 11.\]We can then fill in that $a_1 = 2$ and $a_0 = 1,$ so
\[p(x) = x^3 + 2x + 1.\](Note that we are effectively expressing 136 in base 5: $136 = 1021_5.$)

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = a * x powr n + b * x powr (n-1) + ... + z"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b ... z. a \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> ... \<and> z \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "p 1 = 4"
and h3 : "p 5 = 136"
shows  "p 6 = 229"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The coefficients of the polynomial $p(x)$ are all nonnegative integers.  If $p(1) = 4$ and $p(5) = 136,$ then find $p(6).$ The final Answer is 229
 ### Proof
 Let \[p(x) = a_n x^n + a_{n - 1} x^{n - 1} + \dots + a_1 x + a_0.\]Since $p(1) = 4,$ and all the coefficients of $p(x)$ are nonnegative integers, each coefficient $a_i$ of $p(x)$ is at most 4.
 We also know \[p(5) = a_n 5^n + a_{n - 1} 5^{n - 1} + \dots + a_1 5 + a_0 = 136.\]Since $5^4 = 625 > 136,$ the degree $n$ of the polynomial can be at most 3, and we can write \[p(5) = 125a_3 + 25a_2 + 5a_1 + a_0 = 136.\]The only possible values of $a_3$ are 0 and 1.
 Since \[25a_2 + 5a_1 + a_0 \le 25 \cdot 4 + 5 \cdot 4 + 4 = 124 < 136,\]$a_3$ cannot be 0, so $a_3 = 1.$  Then \[25a_2 + 5a_1 + a_0 = 136 - 125 = 11.\]This forces $a_2 = 0,$ so \[5a_1 + a_0 = 11.\]We can then fill in that $a_1 = 2$ and $a_0 = 1,$ so
 \[p(x) = x^3 + 2x + 1.\](Note that we are effectively expressing 136 in base 5: $136 = 1021_5.$)
 Therefore, $p(6) = 6^3 + 2 \cdot 6 + 1 = \boxed{229}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = a * x powr n + b * x powr (n-1) + ... + z"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b ... z. a \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> ... \<and> z \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "p 1 = 4"
and h3 : "p 5 = 136"
shows  "p 6 = 229"
